stream_context.summary: Bonus stream split between modeling an icy, room-based interior (ceiling/lighting/UV tweaks, camera/room layout ideas) and technical engine work: diagnosing a major lighting regression, fixing collision pool allocation issues, and refactoring the mirror/mural system until “Mirror Mario” works again. Kaze also lays out a concrete release plan (patch-only, emulator-first, then potentially N64-only) and discusses emulator accuracy/performance tradeoffs tied to X2→X3 rendering changes.
stream_context.significance_reason: Kaze completes a substantial mirror/mural system redesign (simpler data model, easier authoring) and articulates a specific staged release strategy (v1 + v1.1 emulator/N64, then possibly dropping emulator support for speed). He also identifies a serious lighting regression affecting demo readiness and introduces per-level collision allocation changes to address an “unplayable” collision issue.

findings.summary: A persistent lighting bug appeared after moving to X3: when a second light source is present (e.g., a star-like light), ambient lighting can reset to zero, making the scene go dark. Kaze can’t yet identify the culprit despite investigating.

Course 3’s environment is being built as a set of discrete rooms with doors/occluders so you generally can’t see through doorways; Kaze expects this structure to make 60 FPS much more achievable because it limits what is rendered at once.

Kaze runs into collision failures likely caused by surface pool limits (too many pool nodes needed when large triangles span many collision cells). He decides to change collision allocation per level (instead of a single global pool size) using his custom memory allocator.

Performance expectations are explicitly framed as “not indicative yet” because room rules/visibility rules are not implemented; in current tests, the engine is effectively rendering far more (even ‘the entire castle’) than it will in the final game.

Kaze reiterates that the main performance bottleneck they identified (including with Sauraen in a prior stream) is RSP, not RDP—one reason Course 1 jumped from ~46 FPS after RSP-side improvements in X3.

He refactors the mirror/mural system into a simpler, more author-friendly design: a flag/parameter-driven approach where the mirror axis is encoded and ranges/points define the mirrored region. During the refactor he discovers confusing/incorrect variable naming (e.g., “Mirror X” actually being Z), fixes axis handling and jaw/scale inversion, and restores Mirror Mario functionality.
findings.quote: This is gonna be the easiest system to add new murals ever.

findings.summary: A mirror room layout problem forces a design change: the mirror placement would clip into the room as originally planned, so Kaze adopts the suggestion to place/move the mirror to the opposite side and potentially extend it vertically (toward the top) to avoid bonk/clipping issues.
Kaze confirms their pipeline uses separate collision meshes rather than sharing visual vertices for collision (noting some N64 games like Banjo-Kazooie share data, but that’s the exception).

Kaze states he cannot physically release the game because Nintendo would sue; instead, he plans to release an official patch containing only his changes, which users apply to their own Mario 64 ROM. He acknowledges people will likely put patched ROMs on EverDrives and that unauthorized Etsy sellers already illegally sell his games, but he won’t officially encourage that.
findings.quote: I will release a patch that will contain only my own changes.

findings.summary: Release roadmap: v1 will run on both emulator and real N64; v1.1 will be a bugfix follow-up after the first large wave of player-found issues. After that, he’s considering dropping emulator support entirely to maximize N64 performance—unless GlideN64 support makes that unnecessary.
findings.quote: Supporting emulators makes the entire game run slower.

findings.summary: He’s skeptical of emulator accuracy long-term (“the N64 is fucked up”), noting Ares currently fails to run the project properly, and that ‘accurate’ emulation will demand higher-end PC hardware—making it less accessible.
Kaze says the decomp PC port won’t run the hack because it doesn’t support the custom/special combiner work he uses; static recompilation might be viable depending on renderer/shader support.
findings.quote: The PC port doesn’t support any of the special combiners I do.

findings.summary: He describes a debugging tactic for unexpected compiler-inserted memcpy calls: his memcpy implementation captures the return-address (RA) via inline assembly and logs it so he can locate and remove the call sites.

Kaze describes narrowly avoiding a spearphishing attempt from a ‘sponsor’ who tried to get him to run an .exe and later pushed a fake Zoom domain; he refused to run the file, spotted the domain trick, and contacted the real GitHub user whose identity was impersonated (someone working in anti-scam software) to help trace the attackers.
findings.quote: I’m not downloading and running an exe file ever, no matter how legit this looks.

findings.summary: He gives a strong (provocative) take that obsession over language choice is often a sign of poor programming, while conceding that specialized constraints can matter (e.g., certain guarantees or low-level considerations).
findings.quote: If you care at all about which programming language you use, that is a very strong indicator that you’re a terrible programmer.

findings.summary: Prompts Kaze on emulator targeting (GlideN64) and the possibility of using tri-strips/tri-steps; this leads Kaze to connect a future performance plan (tri-strips) with his staged release plan and potential emulator-support tradeoffs.
Gives practical modeling feedback/requests (e.g., asking for precision on Goomba King scaling), which triggers Kaze to discover and remove an unwanted scale bone in the model rig.
Referenced as the key collaborator on prior RSP bottleneck investigation and as the person Kaze wants to wait for before attempting deeper F3DEX3/X3 microcode micro-optimizations.

key_stories.title: Spearphishing ‘sponsor’ attempt avoided
key_stories.summary: Kaze recounts a highly convincing scam where an ‘advertiser’ referenced his content and impersonated a real GitHub identity to gain trust. The incident shows the real-world risks of being a mid-to-large creator and how operational security habits affect his work and time.
key_stories.challenge: A fake sponsor tried to get him onto a call by installing an .exe (‘V-deck’) and later directed him to a fake Zoom domain.
key_stories.process: Kaze refused to run any executable, noticed the suspicious domain (zoom.usweb.us), and contacted the real person whose GitHub identity was being impersonated (someone in anti-scam software).
key_stories.outcome: He avoided infection and passed details to the impersonated developer to help trace/locate the infrastructure behind the attack.
key_stories.key_quote: I’m not downloading and running an exe file ever, no matter how legit this looks.

key_stories.title: Mirror/mural system refactor to a simpler authoring model
key_stories.summary: Kaze converts a confusing, error-prone mirror system into a cleaner parameter/flag-driven design that’s easier to extend. This is both a tooling win (faster content creation) and a quality win (fewer axis/transform mistakes).
key_stories.challenge: Mirrors/murals broke due to axis confusion, naming errors, and incorrect inversion/offset logic (including “Mirror X” actually behaving like Z).
key_stories.process: He redesigns the data representation (axis + ranges/point), updates the code to compute transforms consistently, tests each existing mural, and fixes remaining issues (jaw/axis inversion, missing export fields).
key_stories.outcome: Mirror Mario and multiple murals work again; Kaze describes the new system as dramatically easier for adding future murals.
key_stories.key_quote: This is gonna be the easiest system to add new murals ever.

key_stories.title: Collision becomes ‘unplayable’ → per-level allocation plan
key_stories.summary: While building large, flat room geometry, Kaze encounters collision failures tied to surface pool/node limits. He responds by planning a per-level allocation scheme using his own allocator, aiming to make collision robust across levels of very different geometric characteristics.
key_stories.challenge: Collision triangles/cells require too many pool nodes (especially with large triangles spanning many cells), causing invalid collision behavior.
key_stories.process: He diagnoses that the pool/node budget is the likely constraint and decides to adjust collision allocation per level rather than relying on one global configuration.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete engineering direction is set (per-level allocator settings), though final tuning remains for later.

key_stories.title: Release plan shaped by legal constraints and emulator performance costs
key_stories.summary: Kaze lays out how Return to Yoshi’s Island will be shipped: as a patch only, with an initial emulator+N64-compatible release and a quick bugfix follow-up. He then considers dropping emulator support to unlock more aggressive N64 performance, illustrating how platform constraints shape creative/technical decisions.
key_stories.challenge: He can’t distribute the game directly without legal risk, and emulator support forces slower code paths/compatibility compromises.
key_stories.process: He proposes a staged plan: v1 (emulator+N64), v1.1 (bugfix wave), then potentially N64-only optimizations unless GlideN64 can keep compatibility without major costs.
key_stories.outcome: A clearer roadmap emerges that connects legal distribution realities to engineering priorities (RSP/microcode, tri-strips, combiners).
key_stories.key_quote: Supporting emulators makes the entire game run slower.

open_questions.topic: X3 lighting regression (ambient resets to zero when multiple lights exist)
open_questions.context: Kaze describes a post-X3 bug where adding a second light source can make colors go dark as ambient becomes zero; he also suspects emulator-only lighting struct copying (X2 vs X3) may be involved.
questions: When did you first notice the ambient-reset bug (what commit/feature change) and how did you reproduce it reliably?
What’s different about the X2-vs-X3 light structs you’re copying on emulator-only builds, and what’s your current best hypothesis for why ambient disappears?
How close is this issue to blocking the demo—would you ship with compromised lighting on emulator if N64 looks correct, or do you need parity first?

open_questions.topic: Decision point: dropping emulator support after release
open_questions.context: Kaze proposes v1 and v1.1 supporting emulator + N64, then possibly ditching emulator support because it slows the game—unless GlideN64 support makes that unnecessary.
questions: What specific emulator-compatibility requirements are currently forcing slower code paths (lighting, combiners, geometry formats, microcode assumptions)?
What would be the ‘go/no-go’ criteria after v1.1 that makes you commit to N64-only—frame rate targets, bug burden, renderer features like tri-strips?
If you drop emulator support, how will you communicate that to players and preserve a playable ‘emulator build’ for archival/documentary purposes?

open_questions.topic: Future optimization work on X3 / F3DEX3 and tri-strips
open_questions.context: Kaze believes there are still major gains possible in RSP with creative programming, but he wants to wait until Sauraen finishes his work; he also wants tri-strips but isn’t sure how they’re implemented or whether they truly speed things up.
questions: What kind of RSP-side wins do you think are still on the table (vertex transform reuse, command throughput reduction, better batching), and which ones feel most realistic for you to tackle?
What’s your plan for learning the microcode/RSP well enough to contribute—are you thinking experiments, tooling, mentorship from Sauraen, or reading Nintendo-era docs?
What evidence would convince you tri-strips/tri-steps are worth adopting (profiling methodology, test scenes, emulator vs hardware validation)?

open_questions.topic: Room-based layout vs camera/flow problems in Course 3
open_questions.context: Kaze notes a particular room feels ‘weird and janked’ because the camera and short corridor behave poorly; he considers making doors solid for the camera when far away or fusing rooms to reduce room count.
questions: What’s the underlying camera failure mode here—clipping, sudden snaps, or losing spatial readability—and how often does it happen in playtests?
How do you weigh room segmentation (performance/visibility) against navigation feel and camera comfort in tight interiors?
If you fuse rooms to fix camera issues, what’s your fallback plan to keep performance (new occlusion rules, portal rendering, door logic changes)?

open_questions.topic: Distribution realities: patching, EverDrive play, and unauthorized Etsy carts
open_questions.context: Kaze acknowledges unauthorized sellers already sell his work and that patched ROMs can be played on EverDrive, but he won’t encourage piracy while still making the game accessible.
questions: Have you considered any practical steps to reduce Etsy reselling (watermarking, messaging, community reporting), or do you see it as inevitable collateral?
How do you want players to experience the ‘authentic’ version—emulator settings, recommended flashcarts, recommended hardware revisions?
What’s your line between ‘patch-based preservation’ and ‘enabling distribution’ when you publish tools/instructions?
